p: The most resistant species to warming was the sponge Agelas oroides, which did not show any kind of necrotic tissue throughout any of the treatments (Figures 2 and 3). Conversely, the most sensitive species was the stocky morphotype of the cnidarian Parazoanthus axinellae,which showed the first signs of necrosis after only 5 days at 26°C and after only 1–2 days at any of the higher temperatures (Figure 2a). Between these extremes, a whole range of different responses to thermal stress was found, including highly resistant species (upper thermal limit ≥28°C), species with an intermediate response (upper thermal limit = 27°C) and sensitive species (upper thermal limit = 26°C) (Figure 3).
